content:
SECTION 1. TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS. This section includes amendments to various sections of the Leahy-Smith America Invents Act related to advice of counsel, transitional program for covered business method patents, joinder of parties, and dead zones in inter partes review. (d) Dead Zones. Section 311(c) of title 35, United States Code, shall not apply to a petition to institute an inter partes review of a patent that is not described in section 3(n)(1) of the Leahy-Smith America Invents Act. Section 311(c)(1) of title 35, United States Code, is amended by striking "or issuance of a reissue of a patent".

(e) Correct Inventor. Section 135(e) of title 35, United States Code, is amended by striking "correct inventors" and inserting "correct inventor". The effective date of this amendment is retroactive to the Leahy-Smith America Invents Act.

(f) Inventor's Oath or Declaration. Section 115 of title 35. The amendment to Section 115 of title 35, United States Code, requires the applicant to provide necessary oaths, declarations, or assignments before the patent issue fee is paid. Additionally, changes to travel expenses and payment of administrative judges are effective as of September 16, 2011. Effective as of September 16, 2011, amendments were made to Section 154(b) of title 35, United States Code regarding Patent Term Adjustments. These amendments include changes to the commencement of the national stage under section 371 in an international application and the date of commencement of the national stage under section 371 in the international application. Additionally, adjustments were made to the written notice of allowance of the application under section 151. Amendments were made to Section 154(b) of title 35, United States Code regarding Patent Term Adjustments, including changes to the national stage under section 371 in an international application and the written notice of allowance under section 151. Section 373 and financial management clarifications were also addressed in the amendments. Amendments to Section 35, United States Code include changes to administrative costs of the Office for patents and trademarks. Section 135(a) is modified to allow applicants to file a petition for patent. An applicant for patent may file a petition to institute a derivation proceeding in the Office, demonstrating that an individual derived an invention without authorization. If the Director finds the standards are met, a derivation proceeding may be instituted. An invention claimed in a patent issued on an earlier application or published earlier cannot be filed unless a petition is submitted within one year of the patent grant or publication. The effective filing date of the invention in one application must be earlier than any other application to be considered an earlier application. The Director's decision on whether to institute a derivation proceeding is final and not appealable. The provisions of sections 6 and 141 of title 35, United States Code, and section 1295(a)(4)(A) of title 28, United States Code, apply to interference proceedings declared after September 15, 2012. The Patent Trial and Appeal Board may act as the Board of Patent Appeals and Interferences for such proceedings. In each year, 3 members shall be appointed to each Advisory Committee for 3-year terms that shall begin on December 1 of that year. Any vacancy on an Advisory Committee shall be filled within 90 days after it occurs. A new member who is appointed to fill a vacancy shall be appointed to serve for the remainder of the predecessor's term. The Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with the Director, shall designate a Chair and Vice Chair of each Advisory Committee. The Director designates a Chair and Vice Chair for each Advisory Committee from appointed members. If the Chair resigns, the Vice Chair assumes the Chair's functions. The Secretary of Commerce determines the time and manner of amendments taking effect. Three members are appointed to each Advisory Committee annually for 3-year terms starting on December 1. Section 5(a) of title 35, United States Code may terminate the term of an existing Advisory Committee member regardless of the original termination date. Section 123(a) of title 35, United States Code is amended for clarity. The effective date of the amendments is specified in the Act. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on the date of enactment and apply to proceedings started after that date.
